description.narrative: Education programmes are realistically planned and monitored by competent MoE staff at national, provincial and district levels.

Support to UNESCO/IIEP (International Institute for Educational Planning) concerning capacity development within strategic educational planning, within Ministry of Education and Provincial Education Departments in Afghanistan. Agreement covers 2014-2016. Total amount: 32 million SEK.

UNESCO har anhållit om stöd från Sida för programmet "Afghanistan Capacity Development for Educational Planning and Management III" i Afghanistan under perioden 2015-2017 uppgående till totalt 32 millioner SEK.
Insatsen syftar till att förbättra det afghanska utbildningsministeriets planeringskapacitet genom följande: I.) Utbildningsministeriets nationella träningsprogram för planering och styrning inom utbildningssektorn. II.) Utveckling och granskning av utbildningsministeriets policy och dokument. III.) Konsolidering av utbildningsministeriets tekniska kapacitet. IV.) Logistik och stödtjänster.
Insatsen kommer att genomföras av UNESCO:s kategori 1-institut IIEP och UNESCO:s lokalkontor i Kabul i samarbete med det afghanska utbildningsministeriet.
Sida har inte stött tidigare cykler av projektet, men en extern utvärdering har dragit slutsatsen att projektet är ett svar på reella kapacitetsbehov inom utbildningsplanering och management. Dess National Training Program bedöms som välanpassad till den afghanska kontexten och har uppnått erkända resultat. Hållbarhet anses vara projektets primära styrka eftersom det har lyckats skapa en välfungerande struktur och är välintegrerat inom utbildningsministeriet.
Insatsens totala budget uppgår till 32 millioner SEK, vilket innebär att det inte finns andra finansiärer. Inga medel förmedlas från UNESCO till tredjepartsorganisation.

description.narrative: As a result of the intervention, Afghanistan has been able to produce a strong basis for reviving the education system. The final report dated covering 4 years of implementation (1 April 2015 - 30 April 2019) and the Evaluation report from June 2018 identifies the following as the most important outcome-level results achieved: 1. Development and endorsement of NESP-III – the design, elaboration and launch of the National Education Strategic Plan (NESP-III) is one of the major outcomes of the project with direct impact on the country education system. It constitutes the main platform for education policy and the cooperation with international development partners, donors and NGOs. This also includes a better resource allocation and anti-corruption strategies in NESP-III. 2. Establishment of the National Institute for Educational Planning (NIEP) as an independent Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) centre, equipped, accommodating skilled teachers – considered as the most successful TVET centre of the country. 3. The National Training Programme (NTP) on education strategic planning and management is now fully institutionalized, through the NIEP, as part of the MoE. It addresses the technical education management gaps in Afghanistan. According to data from NIEP, as of March 2018, 659 students have been trained which is more than the intended number of students (469) in the original Logical Framework of the project in 2015. The evaluation of the project assesses indirect and direct impact to be a total of 1300, a figure corrected to 2000 in IIEP’s Management Response. 4. Tangible personal behavior changes, professional motivation and better results in daily work were witnessed and reported by all interviewees, especially female participants, as a direct outcome of the trainings. In addition to practical skills/technical knowledge acquired (such as how to develop a comprehensive operational plan, report writing, co-ordination, situation analysis and implementation), the trainings also “tremendously increased [participants] self-confidence, personal curiosity for understanding problems and their interest of work, and has also improved their own work, daily planning, their practice of English and even their computer skills”, according to the evaluation report. 5. Improved capacity in the General Directorate of Planning and Evaluation (DoPE) in Kabul as well as the level of PEDs and DEDs. This includes increased autonomy of PEDs in development of provincial mid-term education plans and Annual Operational Plans. Also, Plan preparation at decentralized level facilitates norm-based resource allocation by MoE. In addition, the project has contributed to the development of MoE Education Reform paper, obtaining presidential support. The paper provides detailed overview of a range of reform priorities and efforts, and their implications for the Ministry's structure and functioning. Also, the evaluation report of the intervention highlights that the intervention has made an important contribution towards increasing women’s participation in Education Sector Planning (ESP) through targeted capacity building activities. Even though the ratios are still low, women show a real willingness and determination to take part in the project. Given the contextual situation, this can be seen as one important success of the project. Overall female participation in the three programmes (41%) indicates that the project could play a significant role in gender mainstreaming and women empowerment. Female interviewees emphasized that the project “played a decisive role in allowing them to demonstrate their capacities to their male colleagues and motivating them to take part of the education planning process”. They also stressed that the project “played an important role for them to increase their self-confidence in their family and daily life”.
